question.title: Java parser and formatter for Atom DateFormat

node.contents: Is there a date formatting tool for Atom Dates.

astNode.text: Is there a date formatting tool for Atom Dates.

elements.contents: Such date values happen to be compatible with the following specifications: [ISO.8601.1988], [W3C.NOTE-datetime-19980827], and [W3C.REC-xmlschema-2-20041028]. Example Date constructs: <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02Z</updated> <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02.25Z</updated> <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02+01:00</updated> <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02.25+01:00</updated>

fragments.text: Such date values happen to be compatible with the following specifications: [ISO.8601.1988], [W3C.NOTE-datetime-19980827], and [W3C.REC-xmlschema-2-20041028]. Example Date constructs:

units.rawText: Such date values happen to be compatible with the following specifications: [ISO.8601.1988], [W3C.NOTE-datetime-19980827], and [W3C.REC-xmlschema-2-20041028]. Example Date constructs: <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02Z</updated> <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02.25Z</updated> <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02+01:00</updated> <updated>2003-12-13T18:30:02.25+01:00</updated>

node.contents: I tried to use Joda ISODateTimeFormat.dateTime(); but it seems it doesn't handle the parsing when there is no milliseconds (2003-12-13T18:30:02Z for exemple).

astNode.text: I tried to use Joda ISODateTimeFormat.dateTime(); but it seems it doesn't handle the parsing when there is no milliseconds (2003-12-13T18:30:02Z for exemple).

node.contents: What is the simplest way to parse all these date formats?

astNode.text: What is the simplest way to parse all these date formats?

node.contents: DateUtils from Apache Commons / Lang has a parseDate method that supports multiple patterns. That may work for you. (The patterns must be formatted according to the SimpleDateFormat syntax)

astNode.text: DateUtils from Apache Commons / Lang has a parseDate method that supports multiple patterns. That may work for you. (The patterns must be formatted according to the SimpleDateFormat syntax)

node.contents: It seems to be xml dateTime. Then the best choice is javax.xml.datatype.XMLGregorianCalendar.

astNode.text: It seems to be xml dateTime. Then the best choice is javax.xml.datatype.XMLGregorianCalendar.

elements.contents: DatatypeFactory f = DatatypeFactory.newInstance(); XMLGregorianCalendar xgc = f.newXMLGregorianCalendar("2003-12-13T18:30:02.25Z"); System.out.println(xgc); System.out.println(xgc.toGregorianCalendar().getTime());

units.rawText: DatatypeFactory f = DatatypeFactory.newInstance(); XMLGregorianCalendar xgc = f.newXMLGregorianCalendar("2003-12-13T18:30:02.25Z"); Systemoutprintln(xgc); Systemoutprintln(xgc.toGregorianCalendar().getTime());

node.contents: Works without any problems, also if there are no milliseconds in the string.

astNode.text: Works without any problems, also if there are no milliseconds in the string.
